title: The surprising key ingredient to the season's best cocktails
text:
Violets have a sweet, floral perfume. The Victorians adored it: by the late 19th century it was used to scent all manner of things, from cold cream to fondant chocolates and tooth powder.

The smell of violets now has some dated associations, but it is experiencing a renaissance, oddly enough, in both perfume and drinks.

Twenty-first-century perfumers have found ways to blend and reinterpret violet's more old-fashioned aspects. "Violet before was perhaps about a more heavy, powdery scent," says Amanda Wicha, a fragrance specialist at Fortnum & Mason. "Now, it is more about lending an iridescence to a fragrance."

Classic contemporary violet scents include Goutal's La Violette and Guerlain's Insolence...
description: Violets have a sweet, floral perfume.
